contentText.text: Emma didn’t consider Sandy’s privacy when setting up the fundraising site…

popText.text: It was so easy to set up the fundraising site – I described what happened to Sandy — that she was in a terrible auto accident; her car was hit by another car in the middle of an intersection. I said she suffered a broken leg, which will require another surgery and a lot of physical therapy. I also talked about her possible brain injury, and how it could be a long time before Sandy might be well enough to return to work at Johnson Controls. I wanted people to know how dire the situation is for Sandy, so that they'll be motivated to donate to her fund.

I'm one of Emma's Facebook friends, and I saw the link to the fundraising site she created for Sandy. I know Emma meant well, but she really shouldn't have discussed Sandy’s medical condition on the site and shouldn’t have brought Johnson Controls into it. I felt like I had to do something, so I reported what I saw.
An employee reported that Emma created a fundraising site and linked the story on Facebook, and that the site revealed Sandy’s private medical history.

It’s clear that Emma was just trying to help, but she should have thought through the consequences of her actions. We must always respect the privacy of others and should never share someone else’s personal information without their permission.
